different people approach it in
different ways I approach it very
musically so to me sound design is not
just making a specific sound but it's
also kind of scoring a movie with sound
effects and in fact very few of us are
engineers it's you know thinking about
what the appropriate sound is kind of
casting sounds in the way that a casting

of our job as sound designers is to kind
of transport ourselves there to imagine
that we're on a boat in the middle of
the Indian Ocean and then imagine what
we would hear so any kind of sound that
we hear in a movie is added after the
movie a shot pretty much yeah yeah
especially with this movie virtually all
of the sounds of that boat and the ocean
around the boat and the gradual
deterioration of the boat were invented

very much the same way you would

of direction did you get from the

they shot most of the movie at Redford's
I line so that we were seeing what he
was seeing and for a sound designer
trying to tell a story that's like a
huge opportunity because you're doing
you're playing with POV and and you get
a chance to kind of modify the sound and
filter it through
the perception of the character so we
were able to actually treat the boat and
the sounds around almost as if there
were another character and as things
were getting more difficult for the
Redford's character the sound started
the change of the in the boat when he
was climbing up to the top of the mast
try to fix the radio the higher he got
the more we started to wash away the
comforting sounds of the boat and the
things that we've gotten used to and we
start focusing just as he does on the

equipment as he's climbing up there
further and further and then in the
distance we here before we see this big
deep low Thunder and what we were trying
to convey was this is a big moment for
him things are about to really really
change and we wanted to hear it the way
he heard it one of the things that you
train yourself to do early as a sound
design areas and not think literally
about sound I've been the right stuff
which was an early film that I worked on
one of the principal sounds of Chuck
Yeager's rocket plane accelerating is me
scraping my fingers on a chalkboard we
had recorded a ferry out in the bay just
the bow wash you know you hang the mic
right down close to it it's got a lot of
spray but it also has a lot of real low
frequency kind of Rumble to it so I just
cut that through the whole scene using
one of these guys little joystick as you
watch the movie as the boats going to
and fro and up and down I would move
this with it if you were listening to
just that it almost makes you seasick
because you feel the whole room kind of
going like this one of the great things
about movie sound is that it's so
people's perception of sound is so
malleable that you can get as a sound
designer as a filmmaker you can get away
with almost anything in terms of sound
because people will tend to accept what
they're presented and you will
unconsciously invent a story to allow it
to make sense I'm shocked how many times
people thought that we recorded a storm
or thought that that that all happened
